help.text: Tar 1.15.1 does not properly warn the user when extracting setuid or setgid files, which may allow local users or remote attackers to gain privileges.
help.markdown:
> Tar 1.15.1 does not properly warn the user when extracting setuid or setgid files, which may allow local users or remote attackers to gain privileges.

|----------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Package        | pkg:deb/debian/tar@1.34%2Bdfsg-1.2%2Bdeb12u1?os_distro=bookworm&os_name=debian&os_version=12 |
| Affected range | >=1.34+dfsg-1.2+deb12u1                                                                      |
| Fixed version  | not fixed                                                                                    |

help.text: A flaw has been discovered in GnuTLS where an application crash can be induced when attempting to verify a specially crafted .pem bundle using the "certtool --verify-chain" command.
help.markdown:
> A flaw has been discovered in GnuTLS where an application crash can be induced when attempting to verify a specially crafted .pem bundle using the "certtool --verify-chain" command.

|                |                                                                                           |
|----------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Package        | pkg:deb/debian/gnutls28@3.7.9-2%2Bdeb12u2?os_distro=bookworm&os_name=debian&os_version=12 |
| Affected range | <3.7.9-2+deb12u3                                                                          |
| Fixed version  | 3.7.9-2+deb12u3                                                                           |

help.text: Certain DNSSEC aspects of the DNS protocol (in RFC 4033, 4034, 4035, 6840, and related RFCs) allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption) via one or more DNSSEC responses, aka the "KeyTrap" issue. One of the concerns is that, when there is a zone with many DNSKEY and RRSIG records, the protocol specification implies that an algorithm must evaluate all combinations of DNSKEY and RRSIG records.
help.markdown:
> Certain DNSSEC aspects of the DNS protocol (in RFC 4033, 4034, 4035, 6840, and related RFCs) allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption) via one or more DNSSEC responses, aka the "KeyTrap" issue. One of the concerns is that, when there is a zone with many DNSKEY and RRSIG records, the protocol specification implies that an algorithm must evaluate all combinations of DNSKEY and RRSIG records.
